data.title: Top 10 Christmas albums for 2018 Yuletide
authors: Keith O'Connor | Special to The Republican
data.meta_description: A look at 10 new album of holiday tunes.
data.text:
Larry Busacca | Getty Images

By KEITH O'CONNOR | Special to The Republican

Music adds a dynamic emotional element to both movies and television shows, and the same holds true for Christmas music, which brings joy to the holiday season and stirs up fond memories.

Christmas music has come a long way from early religious Christian hymns to today's contemporary popular music.

Holiday songs date back as early as the Middle Ages.

In the 1800s, songs like "Silent Night" could be heard in church, but it wasn't until 1857, when "Jingle Bells" was written, that secular music began to enter the holiday scene.

As rock 'n' roll gained popularity in the 1950s, Christmas music took a big turn. There was Elvis Presley's first Christmas album in 1957 followed in 1963 by the groundbreaking "A Christmas Gift for You from Phil Spector," considered by many as "the best Christmas album ever," which opened the doors for a slew of Christmas albums from contemporary artists.

A bountiful list of new Christmas releases from your favorite artists from pop to country and from rock to easy listening and everything in between awaits listeners to add some extra cheer to their holiday.

Here's a list of the Top 10 new entries on this year's musical Christmas list:

Gustavo Caballero | Getty Images

LeAnn Rimes - "It's Christmas, Eve" Original Movie Soundtrack (EverLe Records)

Country songstress LeAnn Rimes, who has more than several Christmas albums to her name, comes up with a soundtrack album from her new Hallmark Channel movie "It's Christmas, Eve."

The nine-track holiday release features three new songs alongside the classic "White Christmas," "Carol of the Bells" and even a Christmas jam.

The poppy "You and Me and Christmas," which opens the album, is an up-tempo gem.

Columbia Records

John Legend - "A Legendary Christmas" (Columbia Records)

With a cute play on words for its title, "A Legendary Christmas" kicks off its 14 tracks with a little help from Stevie Wonder on harmonica for "What Christmas Means to Me."

Legend also gets a little help from jazz artist Esperanza Spalding on "Have Yourself a Merry Little Christmas."

Standouts include an inspired "Silver Bells" and the touching piano only "Waiting for Christmas."

Could be a potential classic.

Brushbranch Records/Surfdog Records

Eric Clapton - "Happy XMAS" (Brushbranch Records/Surfdog Records)

Inevitably each year there is a Christmas album you never expect an artist to undertake.

This year there are two. The first belongs to Eric Clapton, who in his words adds "a slight bluesy tinge" to holiday classics and more contemporary songs, including the Clapton-written "For Love On Christmas Day."

Clapton's own artwork of Santa adorns the cover of his 24th album. There is even a deluxe box set wrapped in a custom red and white faux fur to resemble a classic Santa hat and that includes a flexidisc, ornament and more.

Cleopatra Records

William Shatner - "Shatner Claus: The Christmas Album" (Cleopatra Records)

The season's second unexpected ever Christmas album belongs to William Shatner of "Star Trek" fame.

Who knew Captain Kirk could sing?

He can't, but instead speaks his way through some nicely orchestrated and rockin' songs with the help of some equally unusual guests, including Todd Rundgren, Jethro Tull's Ian Anderson, Iggy Pop, as well as Judy Collins, Brad Paisley and others.

Only for those with discriminating tastes.

RCA Records

Pentatonix - "Christmas Is Here" (RCA Records)

The Grammy Award-winning a cappella sensations are on their fourth Christmas album since 2012.

Now considered a Christmas staple when it comes to holiday music, the kings of harmony are joined on their new recording of Christmas classics and other gems by Kelly Clarkson on "Grown-Up Christmas List" and Maren Morris on "When You Believe."

Republic Records

Jessie J - "This Christmas Day" (Republic Records)

Not what you might expect and a pleasant surprise from the British singer/songwriter whose unconventional music style blends contemporary R&B, pop, hip hop, soul, and other genres.

From lush orchestrations to jazzy big band, Jessie J, for the most part, stays faithful to the classics.

The album includes collaborations with Boyz II Men on "Winter Wonderland" and Babyface on "The Christmas Song," as well as two gorgeous songs produced by David Foster.

It includes a combination of "Rudolph The Red-Nosed Reindeer"/"Jingle Bells" like only Jessie J can do.

Cabin 24 Records

Ingrid Michaelson - "Songs for the Season" (Cabin 24 Records)

Recorded with a full 35-piece orchestra, the indie-pop singer's second full-length Christmas album features the single "Rockin' Around the Christmas Tree," a duet with "America's Got Talent" wunderkind Grace VanderWaal.

Other collaborations include "White Christmas" with Christina Perri (whatever happened to her?), Will Chase on "I'll Be Home for Christmas" and Leslie Odom Jr. on Mariah Carey's hit "All I Want for Christmas Is You."

The album's one original song, a downer called "Happy, Happy Christmas," isn't so happy and is about losing her mother four years ago.

Universal Studios

"The Grinch" motion picture soundtrack (Columbia Records)

The soundtrack from Illumination's new movie reboot features Tyler, the Creator's take on the iconic song "You're a Mean One, Mr. Grinch."

Other contributors of past Christmas chestnuts include Nat King Cole, The Supremes, Run-D.M.C. and more.

The album also includes two instrumental tracks from the score created by Danny Elfman.

Rebecca Sapp | Getty Images

Mike Love - "Reason for the Season" (MELECO Records)

The Beach Boys have their own Christmas albums, and now co-founder and lead singer Mike Love has stepped out with his own interpretations of classic Christmas songs and new seasonal themed tunes.

He's even taken on the iconic Beach Boys' "Little St. Nick." (See if you can tell any difference.)

The album features a guest appearance by Hanson on "Finally It's Christmas" and also features accompaniment by Love's four children.

Matthew Eisman | Getty Images

The Monkees - "Christmas Present" (Rhino Records)

Bootlegs have long been available of Christmas music performed by The Monkees from their once popular television show.

Now comes an official release of newly-recorded versions of classic Christmas songs and new tunes written for the group, including "Unwrap You at Christmas."

In addition to the voices of Micky Dolenz, Michael Nesmith and Peter Tork, the voice of the late Davy Jones is taken from vintage recordings.

Universal Music Group

Bubbling under The Hot 10 are:

Mormon Tabernacle Choir - "A Merry Little Christmas" (Mormon Tabernacle)

Michael McDonald - "Season of Peace - The Christmas Collection" (BMG)

The Mavericks - "Hey! Merry Christmas" (Mono Mundo Recordings)

Martina McBride - "It's the Holiday Season (Broken Bow Records)

Robert Ziegler - "Christmas at the Movies" (Sony Masterworks)

Jesse James Decker - "On This Holiday" (Epic)

Mitch Ryder - "Christmas (Take A Ride)" (Cleopatra)

Engelbert Humperdinck - "Warmest Christmas Wishes" (OK! Good Records)

Los Straitjackets - "Complete Christmas Songbook" (Yep Roc Records)

PJ Morton - "Christmas with PJ" (Morton Records)

Rodney Crowell - "Christmas Everywhere" (New West Records)

Various Artists - "NOW That's What I Call Merry Christmas, 2018" (Universal Music Group)

Various Artists - "A Motown Gospel Christmas" (Motown Records)

Various Artists - "Have Yourself A Swingin' Little Christmas" (Bear Family Records)

Katherine Penfold - "Keep Christmas with You" (Justin Time Records)

Interscope Records

And there is still a lot more.

At least two popular 2017 Christmas albums have been re-released in "deluxe editions." Gwen Stefani's "You Make It Feel Like Christmas" has five additional tracks, including two original songs: "Cheer for the Elves" and "Secret Santa." Electronic violinist Lindsey Stirling's "Warmer in the Winter" has five added tunes including "Somewhere In My Memory" from the "Home Alone" movie.

Also, 70s favorites KC & the Sunshine Band have released a special edition of their "A Sunshine Christmas," originally released in 2015 on the BFD label, while Capitol Records has reissued Nat King Cole's classic 1962 "The Christmas Song" album with five bonus tracks including the "The Christmas Song" duet with his daughter Natalie Cole.

And, Diana Ross has reissued two albums into one collection on Motown Records called "Wonderful Christmas Time." The "Making Spirits Bright" portion of the CD was actually a special Hallmark release, while "A Very Special Season" was only released in Europe, both in 1994.

Real Gone Music

The reissue label Real Gone Music, dedicated to combing the music vaults for long unavailable or never available albums on CD.

This year their output includes five long-gone or "real gone" albums including: "Lorne Greene & the Cast of Bonanza: The Complete Christmas on the Ponderosa" from 1963, The McGuire Sisters' 1958 recording "Seasons' Greetings from The McGuire Sisters," Rod McKuen's "New Carols for Christmas - The Rod McKuen Christmas Album" originally released in in 1971, and conductor "Andre Kostelanetz & His Orchestra - The Complete Christmas Albums" featuring three recordings from 1959, 1963, and 1959 released under the Columbia Records umbrella.

The label's final Christmas release for 2018 is a real gem. "John Klein: A Christmas Sound Spectacular/Let's Ring the Bells All Around the Christmas Tree" combines his two efforts on RCA's once popular Living Stereo imprint from 1959 and 1964 with him displaying his rare talent on the Carillon Americana instrument, consisting of 1,500 ringing bronze caste bells.

Sesame Workshop Catalog

For the young ones, there is the newly-released "It's Christmas Time" from the Sesame Workshop Catalog and performed by Sesame Street characters from the television show's early years.

And, yet another soundtrack, this one from Disney's "The Nutcracker and the Four Realms" on Walt Disney Records, which provides fantasy-inspired instrumentals by James Newton Howard that are perfect for the holiday season. The album also includes the song "Fall On Me" performed by Andrea Bocelli and his son Matteo Bocelli.

Not to forget, there are also a multitude of Christmas albums from Christian artists this year - including "The Advent of Christmas" by Matt Maher on Essential Recordings, "It Must Be Christmas" by David Phelps released by the Gaither Music Group, "The Table: A Christmas Worship Gathering" by Darlene Zschech and "Something's Happening: A Christmas Album" by CeCe Winans on Pure Springs Gospel.

Also, Dove-winning singer and songwriter Lauren Daigle is offering up a deluxe edition of her 2016 album from Centricity Music called "Behold - A Christmas Collection" with three additional songs.
